content: The "Reforming Alternatives to Incarceration and Sentencing to Establish a Better Path for Youth Act of 2015" is also known as the "RAISE Act of 2015." It includes a safety valve for nonviolent youth. Section 3553 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow courts to impose a sentence below a statutory minimum for youth convicted of nonviolent offenses if it would result in substantial injustice and is not necessary for public protection. The court must consider factors such as the nature of the crime, the youth's history, characteristics, and chances of successful rehabilitation. The court can impose a sentence below the statutory minimum for youth convicted of nonviolent offenses if it would result in substantial injustice and is not necessary for public protection. Factors must be considered, and the court shall state the reasons for the sentence in writing. This subsection does not limit any right to appeal. SEC. 3. EARLY RELEASE AND HOME CONFINEMENT FOR YOUTH. Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow for early release and home confinement for youth prisoners. This includes specific conditions for home confinement duration based on the term of imprisonment. The amendment to Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code allows for early release and home confinement for youth prisoners, with specific conditions for home confinement duration based on the term of imprisonment. Placement in a community correction center cannot be used in lieu of home confinement solely based on a mental health diagnosis, and there is a presumption in favor of direct release to home confinement unless specific findings are made by the Director of the Bureau of Prisons. The amendment to Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code allows for early release of youth prisoners who have served half or more of their term for nonviolent offenses and have not violated institutional disciplinary regulations involving violent conduct in the last 2 years. The term 'nonviolent offense' refers to a Federal criminal offense that is not a crime of violence or a sex offense. SEC. 4. SUPERVISED RELEASE CONSIDERATION FOR YOUTH. In the case of a youth serving a sentence of incarceration, a court may reduce the term of imprisonment after the youth has served at least 20 years, based on extraordinary and compelling reasons, including rehabilitation efforts. In cases where a youth is serving a sentence of incarceration, a court may consider reducing the term of imprisonment after at least 20 years based on rehabilitation efforts and other mitigating factors. Additionally, for youth convicted of offenses carrying a mandatory life sentence, the sentencing court must treat the life sentence as discretionary and take into account the age of the youth when determining the appropriate sentence. The term 'youth' refers to individuals 21 years old or younger at the time of the criminal offense for sentencing purposes. SEC. 5. SMARTER PROBATION FOR YOUTH. Section 3565 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a special rule for technical violations of probation. The maximum punishment for such violations is limited to 30 days for the first violation, 60 days for the second violation, and 90 days for third or subsequent violations. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and potentially amend the Federal sentencing guidelines and policy statements. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines for probation and supervised release revocation under section 3565 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 6 amends Section 4042(a) of title 18, United States Code to designate specialized housing and programs for youth in correctional facilities, separate from other offenders, with a focus on education, skills training, reentry, and mental health programs specific to youth needs. The Bureau of Prisons will establish pilot programs in at least 10 judicial districts for youth, including mentorship with formerly incarcerated individuals or volunteers, government service skills training and internships, and service to vulnerable animals. The Department of Justice will establish pilot programs for high-risk youth to avoid criminal conviction through intensive case management and community services, and for victimized youth to address the root causes of their criminal conduct. Additionally, a program will equip youth with skills to provide training and therapy to animals seized by law enforcement and organizations that care for vulnerable animals. The Department of Justice will establish pilot programs for high-risk youth to avoid criminal conviction through intensive case management and community services. The programs will also address the root causes of criminal conduct for victimized youth. Additionally, there will be a program to provide training and therapy to animals seized by law enforcement and organizations caring for vulnerable animals. The Attorney General will report to Congress on the results of the pilot programs, including cost savings, participant numbers, and recidivism rates. The term "youth" refers to individuals 21 years of age or younger at the time of the criminal offense. In this section, "youth" refers to individuals 21 years of age or younger at the time of the criminal offense, and "nonviolent offense" excludes crimes of violence or sex offenses. SEC. 8. RETROACTIVE EFFECT. This Act and its amendments apply to youth regardless of when they enter the Federal criminal justice system.
